name: Project
title: Google
Cloud
Bigtable
Project
description:
Project

Projects are top-level containers in Google Cloud Platform. They store information about billing and authorized users, and they contain Cloud Bigtable data. Each project has a friendly name and a unique ID.

Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Project is the main object for interacting with Cloud Bigtable.

Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Cluster, Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Instance objects are created, accessed, and managed by Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Project.

See Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new and Google::Cloud#bigtable.

examples.caption: Obtaining an instance and the clusters from a project.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

instance = bigtable.instance("my-instance")
clusters = bigtable.clusters # All clusters in the project

methods.name: project_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigtable
Project#project_id
methods.description: The identifier for the Cloud Bigtable project.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new(
  project_id: "my-project",
  credentials: "/path/to/keyfile.json"
)

bigtable.project_id #=> "my-project"

methods.name: instances
title: Google
Cloud
Bigtable
Project#instances
methods.description: Retrieves the list of Bigtable instances for the project.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

instances = bigtable.instances
instances.all do |instance|
  puts instance.instance_id
end

params.name: token
params.description: The token value returned by the last call to instances; indicates that this is a continuation of a call, and that the system should return the next page of data.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

instance = bigtable.instance("my-instance")

if instance
  puts instance.instance_id
end

params.name: instance_id
params.description: Existing instance id.

examples.caption: Create development instance.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

job = bigtable.create_instance(
  "my-instance",
  display_name: "Instance for user data",
  type: :DEVELOPMENT,
  labels: { "env" => "dev"}
) do |clusters|
  clusters.add("test-cluster", "us-east1-b", nodes: 1)
end

job.done? #=> false

# Reload job until completion.
job.wait_until_done
job.done? #=> true

if job.error?
  status = job.error
else
  instance = job.instance
end

examples.caption: Create production instance.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

job = bigtable.create_instance(
  "my-instance",
  display_name: "Instance for user data",
  labels: { "env" => "dev"}
) do |clusters|
  clusters.add("test-cluster", "us-east1-b", nodes: 3, storage_type: :SSD)
end

job.done? #=> false

# To block until the operation completes.
job.wait_until_done
job.done? #=> true

if job.error?
  status = job.error
else
  instance = job.instance
end

params.name: instance_id
params.description: The unique identifier for the instance, which cannot be changed after the instance is created. Values are of the form [a-z][-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9] and must be between 6 and 30 characters in length. Required.

params.name: display_name
params.description:
The descriptive name for this instance as it
appears in UIs. Must be unique per project and between 4 and 30
characters in length.

params.name: type
params.description: The type of the instance. Valid values are :DEVELOPMENT or :PRODUCTION. Default :PRODUCTION instance will created if left blank.

params.name: labels
params.description:
labels Cloud Labels are a flexible and lightweight mechanism for organizing cloud resources into groups that reflect a customer’s organizational needs and deployment strategies. Cloud Labels can be used to filter collections of resources. They can be used to control how resource metrics are aggregated. And they can be used as arguments to policy management rules (e.g. route, firewall, load balancing, etc.).

  • Label keys must be between 1 and 63 characters long and must conform to the following regular expression: [a-z]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?.
  • Label values must be between 0 and 63 characters long and must conform to the regular expression ([a-z]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?)?.
  • No more than 64 labels can be associated with a given resource.

params.name: clusters
params.description: (See Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Instance::ClusterMap) If passed as an empty use code block to add clusters. Minimum one cluster must be specified.

params.name: yield
params.description: A block for adding clusters.

params.name: yield.Cluster
params.description: map of cluster name and cluster object. (See Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Instance::ClusterMap)

returns.description:
The job representing the long-running, asynchronous processing of
an instance create operation.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

bigtable.clusters.all do |cluster|
  puts cluster.cluster_id
  puts cluster.ready?
end

params.name: token
params.description: The token value returned by the last call to clusters; indicates that this is a continuation of a call, and that the system should return the next page of data.

examples.caption: Get tables
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

bigtable.tables("my-instance").all do |table|
  puts table.name
  puts table.column_families
end

params.name: instance_id
params.description: Existing instance Id.

examples.caption: Get table with schema only view
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

table = bigtable.table("my-instance", "my-table")
if table
  p table.name
  p table.column_families
end

examples.caption: Get table with all fields. Clusters states, column families
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

table = bigtable.table("my-instance", "my-table", view: :FULL)
if table
  puts table.name
  p table.column_families
  p table.cluster_states
end

params.name: instance_id
params.description: Existing instance Id.

params.name: table_id
params.description: Existing table Id.

params.name: view
params.description:
Optional. Table view type. Default :SCHEMA_VIEW Valid view types are.

  • :NAME_ONLY - Only populates name
  • :SCHEMA_VIEW - Only populates name and fields related to the table’s schema
  • :REPLICATION_VIEW - Only populates name and fields related to the table’s replication state.
  • :FULL - Populates all fields

methods.name: create_table
title: Google
Cloud
Bigtable
Project#create_table
methods.description:
Creates a new table in the specified instance. The table can be created with a full set of initial column families, specified in the request.

(See Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Instance::ColumnFamilyMap) GC Rules for column family see Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule)

examples.caption: Create table without column family
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

table = bigtable.create_table("my-instance", "my-table")
puts table.name

examples.caption: Create table with column families and initial splits.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

initial_splits = ["user-00001", "user-100000", "others"]
table = bigtable.create_table("my-instance", "my-table", initial_splits: initial_splits) do |column_families|
  column_families.add('cf1', Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_versions(5))
  column_families.add('cf2', Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_age(600))

  gc_rule = Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.union(
    Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_age(1800),
    Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_versions(3)
  )
  column_families.add('cf3', gc_rule)
end

p table

params.name: instance_id
params.description: The unique Id of the instance in which to create the table.

params.name: table_id
params.description:
The name by which the new table should be referred to within the parent
instance, e.g., +foobar+

params.name: column_families
params.description: (See Google::Cloud::Bigtable::Table::ColumnFamilyMap) If passed as an empty use code block to add column families.

params.name: granularity
params.description: The granularity at which timestamps are stored in this table. Timestamps not matching the granularity will be rejected. Valid values are :MILLIS. If unspecified, the value will be set to :MILLIS

params.name: initial_splits
params.description:
The optional list of row keys that will be used to initially split the table into several tablets (tablets are similar to HBase regions). Given two split keys, +s1+ and +s2+, three tablets will be created, spanning the key ranges: +[, s1), [s1, s2), [s2, )+.

Example:

  • Row keys := [“a”, “apple”, “custom”, “customer_1”, “customer_2”,+ +”other”, “zz”]
  • initial_split_keys := +[“apple”, “customer_1”, “customer_2”, “other”]+
  • Key assignment:
    • Tablet 1 : +[, apple) => “a”.+
    • Tablet 2 : +[apple, customer_1) => “apple”,.+
    • Tablet 3 : +[customer_1, customer_2) => “customer_1”.+
    • Tablet 4 : +[customer_2, other) => “customer_2”.+
    • Tablet 5 : +[other, ) => “other”,.+ A hash of the same form as Google::Bigtable::Admin::V2::CreateTableRequest::Split can also be provided.

params.name: yield
params.description: A block for adding column_families.

params.name: yield.Map
params.description: of family name and column family object.

methods.name: delete_table
title: Google
Cloud
Bigtable
Project#delete_table
methods.description: Permanently deletes a specified table and all of its data.

examples.caption: Create table with column families and initial splits.

params.name: instance_id
params.description: The unique Id of the instance in which table is exists.

params.name: table_id
params.description:
The unique name of the table to be deleted.
e.g., +foobar+

methods.name: modify_column_families
title: Google
Cloud
Bigtable
Project#modify_column_families
methods.description: Performs a series of column family modifications on the specified table. Either all or none of the modifications will occur before this method returns, but data requests received prior to that point may see a table where only some modifications have taken effect.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigtable"

bigtable = Google::Cloud::Bigtable.new

modifications = []
modifications << Google::Cloud::Bigtable::ColumnFamily.create_modification(
  "cf1", Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_age(600))
)

modifications << Google::Cloud::Bigtable::ColumnFamily.update_modification(
  "cf2", Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_versions(5)
)

gc_rule_1 = Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_versions(3)
gc_rule_2 = Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_age(600)
modifications << Google::Cloud::Bigtable::ColumnFamily.update_modification(
  "cf3", Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.union(gc_rule_1, gc_rule_2)
)

max_age_gc_rule = Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.max_age(300)
modifications << Google::Cloud::Bigtable::ColumnFamily.update_modification(
  "cf4", Google::Cloud::Bigtable::GcRule.union(max_version_gc_rule)
)

modifications << Google::Cloud::Bigtable::ColumnFamily.drop_modification("cf5")

table = bigtable.modify_column_families("my-instance", "my-table", modifications)

p table.column_families

params.name: instance_id
params.description: The unique Id of the instance in which table is exists.

params.name: table_id
params.description: The unique Id of the table whose families should be modified.

params.name: modifications
params.description:
Modifications to be atomically applied to the specified table’s families.
Entries are applied in order, meaning that earlier modifications can be
masked by later ones (in the case of repeated updates to the same family,
for example).
